datafield.subfield: The experiment editor: supporting inquiry-based learning with virtual labs

Inquiry-based learning is a pedagogical approach where students are motivated to pose their own questions when facing problems or scenarios. In physics learning, students are turned into scientists who carry out experiments, collect and analyze data, formulate and evaluate hypotheses, and so on. Lab experimentation is essential for inquiry-based learning, yet there is a drawback with traditional hands-on labs in the high costs associated with equipment, space, and maintenance staff. Virtual laboratories are helpful to reduce these costs. This paper enriches the virtual lab ecosystem by providing an integrated environment to automate experimentation tasks. In particular, our environment supports: (i) scripting and running experiments on virtual labs, and (ii) collecting and analyzing data from the experiments. The current implementation of our environment supports virtual labs created with the authoring tool Easy Java/Javascript Simulations. Since there are public repositories with hundreds of freely available labs created with this tool, the potential applicability to our environment is considerable.

(i) Virtual labs: EjsS VLs are standalone applications that can be run independently. EE supports loading EjsS VLs, running them, and exchanging information with them by accessing their public variables and methods

(ii) Data Tool: the Data Tool program is an open source project, created by Brown and Christian, and available at OSP : It supports plotting data, computing basic statistical information (e.g., mean, standard deviation, etc), computing linear, quadratic or cubic fits, showing the slope (tangent) and the area under a curve, etc. EE embeds Data Tool, enabling this way of collecting and analyzing data from experiments in a single integrated environment. In figure, 1: #ejpaa5dc1f1, Data Tool is opened through the EE and used to plot the position of the block against the time

(iii) Experiment Editor Front Panel: the most original contribution of this work is a language to specify experiments, and its corresponding editor and interpreter.The editor front panel provides one tab for each experiment defined for a VL. The main window is used for coding the experiment. On the right, there is a set of buttons with different functions: loading a VL, adding or closing experiments, launching the Data Tool, showing help and information about variables of the laboratories, and so on. The lower part shows a log window to see error messages when an experiment is run, indicating a diagnosis of these errors and the line in which they have been detected. Finally, figure, 1: #ejpaa5dc1f1 also shows how a user could access the variables that define the size and the mass of the block in the presented VL. For this task, EE provides a window with a list of the variables defined in the VL, as well as some information related to them (the type of the variable and its default value). In the example, after changing the values for the size and mass of the block, a line of code is introduced to run the VL and wait until the evolution stops. Finally, the last order in the code is used to finish the experiment.To provide the maximum interactivity, the experiment language is interpreted. Thus, users avoid recompiling the experiments (neither the VLs) over and over with every change they make to their experiments. Instead, they just run the code and see the results immediately.The experiment language is Turing complete (it provides loops, if-then-else commands, supports defining functions, importing external libraries, etc). Furthermore, the language includes commands to control the execution of the experiments. Table, 1: #ejpaa5dc1t1 summarizes the most prominent of such commands
